block.p: Healing Jazz MONDAY -- Kenny Barron, Donald Byrd, Tommy Flanagan, Etta Jones, Jimmy Heath and other jazz musicians will perform at Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, at the 12th annual Evening With Friends of Charlie Parker gala and concert. The event will raise money for the drug and alcohol prevention and treatment programs of the Veritas Therapeutic Community, which runs clinics in New York and Barryville, N.Y. The evening begins with a reception at 6, followed by dinner at 7 and the concert at 8:30. Tickets, $250, from (212) 590-2136, or $45 for the concert alone, from (212) 307-7171.

A Home for Religious Art TUESDAY -- Proceeds of a dinner will go to the renovation of a building in East Harlem that will house the National Museum of Catholic Art and History. The museum, scheduled to open in fall 2001, will include permanent collections, a theater and a library. The meal, prepared by Glorious Food and the restaurant Rao's, will be served under a tent at East 115th Street and Pleasant Avenue. Cocktails at 6 will be followed by dinner and entertainment, at 7:30, by Michael Amante, a pop vocalist. Tickets, $500, from (212) 828-9700.

Journalism Honors WEDNESDAY -- Columbia University will hold a scholarship dinner in the rotunda of its Low Memorial Library, where the annual Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for outstanding reporting on Latin America will be awarded. The black-tie evening begins with cocktails at 6:30, followed by dinner and the awards. Proceeds go to the International Scholarship Fund, which allows students from the Americas to attend Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism. Guests enter the campus at Broadway and 116th street. Tickets, $500, from (212) 997-0100.

Crafts at the Pierre WEDNESDAY -- The American Craft Museum will raise money for its education and exhibition programs at a dinner and dance at the Pierre. Black tie. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8 and dancing to the music of Gerard Carelli and His Orchestra. Tickets, $500, from (212) 956-3535.

Helping Hospitals OCT. 2 -- The annual dinner-dance to raise money for the 39 hospitals of the United Hospital Fund will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria. The black-tie event will honor Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, and Marie Lam, the chairwoman of the Chinatown Health Clinic. Cocktails at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 494-0733.

For Medical Research OCT. 2 -- Katie Couric, Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick will be the hosts of a dinner and auction for Project A.L.S., which supports research on amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, known as Lou Gehrig's disease, and other motor neuron diseases. The evening, at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, will begin with a cocktail reception at 6, followed by dinner at 7. The auction will feature a trip for two to Europe that will include a two-week cruise. Tickets, $1,000, or $500 for dinner and the auction only, from (212) 560-7278.

Opening Night at Carnegie Hall OCT. 3 -- The 110th season at Carnegie Hall will open with the conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi and the Cleveland Orchestra performing Robert Schumann's Symphony No. 2 in C major. The event, which begins with a cocktail reception at 5:30, will benefit Carnegie Hall's programs, including one that brings free concerts to New York neighborhoods. The concert, at 7, will be followed by a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. Transportation between Carnegie Hall and the hotel will be provided. Tickets, $1,000, or $500 for cocktails and the performance only, from (212) 903-9679. Tickets for the concert alone are $35 and up, from (212) 247-7800.

A Run on the Rink OCT. 3 -- The Ice Theater of New York will open a three-day run at the Sky Rink at the Chelsea Piers with a benefit dinner and show. The evening, to begin with the program of ice dancing at 7, will raise money for the organization and its school, which provides free instruction and free performances for New York public school children. A cocktail reception will follow at 8, and dinner at 8:30. Tickets, $300, or $20 for the show alone, from (212) 929-5811.
